SDG_GOAL: 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
SDG_TARGET: 3.1: By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS:
3.1.2: Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel

3.7.1: Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods

3.7.2: Adolescent birth rate (aged 10–14 years; aged 15–19 years) per 1,000 women in that age group
STAT_CONC_DEF:
Definition

Maternal mortality ratio is defined as deaths during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days (MICS) (or 2 months DHS) of termination excluding accidents and acts of violence, per 100,000 live births.

Concepts

Maternal death: The death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days (MICS and ICDS) (or 2 months DHS) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management (from direct or indirect obstetric death), but not from accidental or incidental causes.
SOURCE_TYPE:
Different surveys provide data at different years for this indicator

Demographic Health Survey (DHS):

The primary objective of the survey is to provide current demographic and health information for use by policymakers, planners, researchers and programme managers. The survey will thus assist policy makers and programme managers in evaluating and designing programmes and strategies for improving the health of the country’s population.

Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS):

The Inter-Censal Demographic Survey (ICDS) (2017) is a household based survey, which is conducted five years after a decennial census. It covers the whole country (all the ten provinces).

The aim of the survey is to gather information on population size and structure, population Distribution, migration, household characteristics, education, activity and labour force as well as mortality and orphanhood.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS):

The survey is designed to provide high quality data for assessing the situation of children, adolescents, women and households in Zimbabwe
COLL_METHOD:
DHS

ICDS

MICS

Sample design

The 2012 Zimbabwe Population Census was used as the sampling frame for the 2015 ZDHS.

Sample design

The sample design for the 2017 ICDS is two stages, with Enumeration Areas (EAs) as the first stage and households as the second stage sampling units. In total, 400 EAs were selected with probability proportional to size (PPS), the measure of size being the number of households enumerated in the 2012 population census. The 2017 ICDS sample was stratified by province and urban/rural.

Sample design

Sample size

The 2015 DHS sample was selected with a stratified, two-stage cluster design. The 2015 DHS sample included 400 enumeration areas: 166 in urban areas and 234 in rural areas. A representative sample of 11,196 households was selected for the 2015 DHS.

Sample size

A representative probability sample of 11,200 private households was selected for 2017 ICDS. The ICDS was designed to produce estimates at national and provincial levels as well as for rural and urban areas.

Sample size

A total of 462 clusters and 12,012 households were selected at the national level.

Questionnaire design

Four questionnaires were used for the 2015 DHS: the Household Questionnaire, the Woman’s Questionnaire, the Man’s Questionnaire, and the Biomarker Questionnaire.

Women age 15-49 and men age 15-54 who were either permanent residents of the selected households or visitors who stayed in the household the night before the survey were eligible for interviewing.

Questionnaire design

The principal instrument used to collect primary data was the structured questionnaire uploaded on tablet which was administered through face-to-face interviews.

The questionnaire asks whether every birth of a child in the household has been registered.

Questionnaire design

Six questionnaires were used in the survey, i.e. (i) Household questionnaire, (ii) Water and Sanitation, (iii) Individual Men/Women, (v) Children Age 5-17 yrs and (vi) Children under 5 yrs.

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI), with the option to choose English, Shona, or Ndebele for each questionnaire.

Type of interview

Face to face Interviews were conducted with household heads. For the first time, the Zimbabwe ICDS used Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI) using mobiles devices

Type of interview

Household based interview using Computer Assisted Personal Interviews (CAPI).

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place over a 6-month period from July 6 to December 20, 2015.

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork took place on 18-22 August 2017.

Duration of fieldwork

Fieldwork began in January 2019 and was concluded in April 2019.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 25 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and field procedures, a detailed review of the questionnaire content, and mock interviews between participants in the classroom. The trainees also had 3 days of field practice.

Interviewer training

Training of trainers was conducted 3-4 August 2017. Training of field staff for the main survey was conducted from 7-11 August 2017.

Interviewer training

Training was done in 35 days and included lectures on interviewing techniques and questionnaire content, mock interviews to gain practical experience. The trainees also had 4 days of field practice

Response rate

A total of 10,534 households were successfully interviewed, yielding a response rate of 99 percent.

Response rate

The response rate was 92.2 %.

Response rate

The household response rate was 98 % while the Water Quality Testing yielded a response rate of 95.6%. Overall response rate of 92.8; 87.1; 96.1 and 96.3 percent were yielded for the individual interviews of women, men, under age 5 and children age 5-17 years, respectively.
FREQ_COLL:
DHS: Every 5 years

ICDS: The survey is conducted every tenth year.

MICS: Next data collection is planned for 2024.
REL_CAL_POLICY:
DHS: Every 5 years

ICDS: The next release is expected in 2027.

MICS: Preliminary results are normally produced 02 months after data collection, while the final results should be available after -04 months
INST_MANDATE: The data collection and production of statistics for this indicator adhere to the census and Statistics Act of Zimbabwe.
RATIONALE: The maternal mortality ratio depicts the risk of death, which a woman faces with pregnancy.
REC_USE_LIM: It is important to note that the indicator value of maternal mortality ratio represents the period of seven years before the survey and has a significant confidence interval.
DATA_COMP: Calculated as the age-adjusted maternal mortality rate times 100 divided by the age-adjusted general fertility rate.
DATA_VALIDATION:
DHS: CSPro was used for data editing, weighting, cleaning, and tabulation. In ZIMSTAT’s central office, data received from the supervisor’s tablets were registered and checked for inconsistencies and outliers. Data editing and cleaning included structure and internal consistency checks to ensure the completeness of work in the field. Any anomalies were communicated to the respective team through the technical team and the team supervisor. The corrected results were then re-sent to the central office.

ICDS: Steps undertaken to achieve this included field questionnaire editing, pre-programmed data entry template with in-built skipping and validation checks.

Data was merged into one data set by system developers who then analyzed and produced required tables using CSPro and SAS.

MICS: During data collection, the field supervisor is responsible for reviewing paper questionnaires for completeness and consistency before entering data into a tablet equipped with a data entry programme.

After the completion of data entry, data is cleaned by conducting internal tests for outlier answers and comprehensive audit rules. SPSS Version 24 was used to analyse data and Model syntax and tabulation plan developed by UNICEF were customized and used for this purpose.
DOC_METHOD: Global metadata prepared by custodian agencies are available for the indicator.
QUALITY_MGMNT: ZIMSTAT follows the recommendations of the UN Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, the African Charter on Statistics and UN National Quality Assurance Framework.
COVERAGE:
DHS: The survey is conducted since 1988. The survey is conducted approximately every 5 years.

The indicator is available age groups.

ICDS: The survey is conducted every tenth year. The first post-independence survey was in 1987, the second in 1997 and the third in 2007.

Data is disaggregated by age groups.

MICS: The indicator is available since 2014. The survey is conducted every 5 years.

The indicator is available by age groups.
COMPARABILITY:
DHS and MICS/ICDS use different definition of maternal mortality as DHS’ questionnaire refer to deaths within 2 months following a birth rather than 42 days following a birth.

ICDS asks if a death to a female age 15-49 years had occurred in the household within the last 12 months, while MICS and DHS ask about occurrence within the past 7 years.
